description: Master the two most powerful CSS layout systems: Flexible Box (Flexbox) for 1D layouts and CSS Grid for 2D layouts.

slides.title: Why Flexbox?
Flex Direction
Justify Content
slides.content:
# Justify Content â†”ï¸

The `justify-content` property implies how to align the flex items along the **main axis** (usually horizontal).

- `flex-start` (default)
- `flex-end`: Items packed at end.
- `center`: Items centered.
- `space-between`: Items evenly distributed (first at start, last at end).
- `space-around`: Items evenly distributed with equal space around them.

slides.title: Flex Wrap
Flex Items
slides.content:
# Flex Item Properties ðŸ§©

Controlling individual items:

- `flex-grow`: Defines the ability to grow (e.g., `1` to fill space, `2` to take twice as much).
- `flex-shrink`: Defines the ability to shrink.
- `flex-basis`: Defines the default size before growing/shrinking.

Shorthand:
`flex: 1;` (grow: 1, shrink: 1, basis: 0%)

Flex vs Grid
slides.content:
# Flex vs Grid ðŸ¥Š

When to use what?

| Feature | Flexbox | Grid |
|---------|---------|------|
| Layout | 1D (Row OR Col) | 2D (Row AND Col) |
| Alignment | Content-first | Layout-first |
| Gap | Supported | Supported |
| Overlap | Hard | Easy |

> ðŸ’¡ **Pro Tip:** Use Grid for the main page layout, and Flexbox for aligning items inside the grid cells (like navigation bars or card contents).

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Modern Layouts ðŸŽ“

Say goodbye to `float`!

- **Flexbox:** `display: flex`. Control direction (`row`/`column`), alignment (`justify`/`align`), and item sizing (`flex-grow`).
- **Grid:** `display: grid`. Define `template-columns`, `gap`, and `areas`.
- **Strategy:** Combine them for ultimate power.
